text_chunk:
1. Purpose
The purpose of this Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) is to establish governance and standard practices for the Accion Global Technology Operations (GT Ops) team in the management and operation of the Microsoft 365 tenant.

2. Scope
This SOP applies to all activities related to the administration, configuration, security, and operation of the Microsoft 365 tenant at Accion.
source: SOP - Management and Operation of Microsoft 365.pdf

text_chunk:
3. Roles & Responsibilities

3.1. GT Ops Team
Executes day-to-day management of the Microsoft 365 tenant in accordance with this SOP. Ensures compliance with established security and governance requirements.

3.2. GT Security Team
Defines and enforces security baselines, monitoring, and incident response policies for the Microsoft 365 tenant. Reviews and approves tenant changes with security implications.

3.3. GT Ops Leadership
Provides oversight and ensures alignment of tenant management with organizational policies and business objectives. Approves changes in this SOP.
source: SOP - Management and Operation of Microsoft 365.pdf

text_chunk:
4. Definitions

4.1. Users: Individual internal accounts representing employees, interns, externs, consultants, or service identities within the Microsoft 365 tenant.

4.2. External Users: Individuals (Guests) outside the organization (partners, vendors, contractors, or customers) who are granted limited, controlled access to organizational resources such as Teams, SharePoint, or other Microsoft 365 services.

4.3. Groups: Collections of users created for access control, license assignment, and communication purposes. Includes security, distribution, and Microsoft 365 groups.

4.4. Administrators: Accounts with elevated privileges to manage tenant settings, services, and resources. Includes roles such as Global Administrator, Exchange Administrator, and Security Administrator.

4.5. Conditional Access: Policies that control access to Microsoft 365 resources based on user, device, location, and risk signals to enforce security requirements like MFA or device compliance.

4.6. Enterprise Applications: Third-party or internal applications integrated into the tenant that require access to Microsoft 365 services and data.

4.7. Intune: Microsoft endpoint management service used to enroll, configure, secure, and monitor corporate and BYOD devices.

4.8. Teams: Collaboration platform within Microsoft 365 for chat, meetings, and shared resources, including lifecycle management, external access, and governance.

4.9. SharePoint: Platform for document management, collaboration, and intranet content, including site collection governance, permissions, and external sharing.

4.10. Exchange: Microsoft 365 email and calendaring service, including mailbox management, distribution lists, retention policies, and security controls.

4.11. Copilot: Microsoft Al assistant (Copilot Chat, 365 Copilot) functionality that supports productivity within Microsoft 365 applications.

4.12. Licensing: Management of Microsoft 365 subscription entitlements assigned to users or groups, including role-based allocation, compliance, and monitoring of license usage.

4.13. Backup: A cloud-to-cloud solution that securely copies and stores Microsoft 365 data...
source: SOP - Management and Operation of Microsoft 365.pdf

text_chunk:
5.1. Users

5.1.1. All user accounts must be provisioned though approved HR and GT workflows.

5.1.2. Multi-factor authentication (MFA) is required for all user accounts, including privileged and service accounts. Where applicable, service accounts may be exempted from MFA enforcement via conditional access policies.

5.1.3. A break-glass account with Global Administrator privileges must be established in the tenant. The credentials for this account must be securely stored in the Accion "GT-Red" Vault and maintained as a physical copy with two GT team members, including one from GT Security team and one from GT Ops leadership.

5.1.4. User naming conventions and standardized properties must be consistently applied across Entra ID. Refer to "Section 6.1 - M365 Naming Conventions and Standardized Properties".

5.1.5. Inactive users must be blocked from accessing resources in the tenant.

5.1.6. Employee departures/terminations/offboarding must be generally handled in the M365 tenant as follows, and in this order:
5.1.6.1. Block user sign-in and revoke active refresh tokens by signing user out from all devices and sessions.
5.1.6.2. Update Department property by prepending with_INACTIVE_. Example: _INACTIVE_Accion Advisory.
5.1.6.3. Remove user from all Distribution Groups (DLs).
5.1.6.4. Hide user from Exchange global address list (GAL).
5.1.6.5. Set auto-away messages internally and externally. Refer to "Section 6.1 M365 Naming Conventions and Standardized Properties" for the Auto-Away templates.
5.1.6.6. If required, assign a delegate to access OneDrive files.
5.1.6.7. If applicable, reassign ownership of Teams, Groups, and SharePoint sites the user owned.
5.1.6.8. Convert user's mailbox to Shared Mailbox.
5.1.6.8.1. If required, delegate access to designated supervisor(s). Email forwarding is not recommended unless there is a strong justification.
5.1.6.9. Retire/Wipe devices from Intune (if company-managed).
5.1.6.10. Disable user account.
5.1.6.11. Revoke or reassign licenses.
source: SOP - Management and Operation of Microsoft 365.pdf

text_chunk:
5.2. External Users

5.2.1. External users (Guests) must be provisioned through Microsoft Entra ID guest accounts or approved sharing mechanisms in Microsoft 365 (e.g., Teams or SharePoint).

5.2.2. Access must be restricted to the minimum resources required and managed using security groups where possible.

5.2.3. Baseline Conditional Access policies must be applied to external accounts, including MFA requirements.

5.2.4. Guest access permissions in Teams and SharePoint must be monitored and reviewed on a recurring basis.

5.2.5. External user accounts must be deactivated or removed promptly when no longer required.
source: SOP - Management and Operation of Microsoft 365.pdf

text_chunk:
5.3. Groups

5.3.1. Group membership must follow least-privilege principles.

5.3.2. All groups must have a documented purpose which will be summarized in the description field of the group during setup.

5.3.3. Security groups must be used as standard practice for license assignment and role-based access control (RBAC) throughout tenant resources.

5.3.4. Dynamic groups must be thoroughly tested and validated before using them in production.

5.3.5. All security groups names must have the ~sec_prefix.

5.3.6. M365 Groups should be used for collaboration and communication.

5.3.7. Group naming conventions must be used consistently. Refer to "Section 6.1 - M365 Naming Conventions and Standardized Properties".
source: SOP - Management and Operation of Microsoft 365.pdf

text_chunk:
5.4. Administrators

5.4.1. All administrative roles must be assigned based on least-privilege principles.

5.4.2. Global Administrator and other elevated accounts must be tracked and regularly reviewed.

5.4.3. Administrators with elevated privileges, including Global Administrator and Security Administrator roles, must be configured as separate accounts distinct from standard employee user accounts. Such Administrators accounts will follow the naming conventions outlined per "Section 6.1 - M365 Naming Conventions and Standardized Properties".
source: SOP - Management and Operation of Microsoft 365.pdf

text_chunk:
5.5. Conditional Access

5.5.1. Baseline Conditional Access policies must apply to all users, including administrators.

5.5.2. Conditional Access policies must enforce MFA, device compliance, and location-based restrictions where relevant.

5.5.3. Except for break glass and service accounts, no user account may be excluded from Conditional Access policies without formal approval. Refer to "Section 6.3 - Information Security Exception Request Form".

5.5.4. Conditional Access policies must be reviewed and adjusted regularly to reflect evolving business and security requirements.

5.5.5. Inclusions and exclusions for Conditional Access policies must be managed through security groups rather than assigned to individual user accounts.
source: SOP - Management and Operation of Microsoft 365.pdf

text_chunk:
5.6. Enterprise Applications

5.6.1. All applications must be assessed for their data access scope before integration.

5.6.2. Where applicable and possible, SSO authentication must be setup on applications, with security group(s) assignments.
5.6.2.1. If the SSO setup involves configuring a SAML certificate, the notification email on that certificate must be set to GTOps@accion.org.

5.6.3. Where applicable and possible, SCIM (System for Cross-domain Identity Management) should be setup on applications that support it to enable richer identity management and automatic Provisioning/Deprovisioning.

5.6.4. Self-service user consent is restricted to prevent unverified or high-risk apps. Users can request admin consent to applications.

5.6.5. Tenant-wide application consent requires prior admin review and documented business justification.

5.6.6. Enterprise applications must be reviewed yearly. Unused or high-risk apps must be removed promptly.
source: SOP - Management and Operation of Microsoft 365.pdf

text_chunk:
5.7. Intune

5.7.1. All organization-owned devices must be enrolled in Intune.

5.7.2. Device enrollment must follow approved procedures for each device type.

5.7.3. Compliance policies must be integrated with Conditional Access to enforce secure access.

5.7.4. Device compliance reports must be reviewed periodically to ensure adherence.

5.7.5. The Company Portal app is the central repository of all managed applications and must be deployed to all enrolled devices.

5.7.6. All managed applications must be tested thoroughly before assignment and rollout.

5.7.7. Where applicable, all managed applications must have the following App Information properties defined before assignment and rollout:
5.7.7.1. Description
5.7.7.2. Publisher
5.7.7.3. Category
5.7.7.4. Logo

5.7.8. Dedicated assignment security groups must be used, following the naming conventions outlined in "Section 6.1 - M365 Naming Conventions and Standardized Properties".

5.7.9. Where applicable, dynamic security groups should be used for org-wide or rule-based assignments.

5.7.10. Where applicable, assignment filters should be used to complement org-wide or rule-based assignments.

5.7.11. Device configuration profiles and scripts must be thoroughly tested before rollout. During testing, configuration profiles must have the following name prefix: _TESTING_<ConfigProfileName>

5.7.12. When devices are unenrolled in Intune, they must be dispositioned accordingly in Entra ID. For example, if the device was unenrolled in Intune because of a user offboarding and device wipe, the device must be disabled in Entra ID.

5.7.13. For end user computers and laptops naming conventions, refer to "Section 6.1 M365 Naming Conventions and Standardized Properties".
source: SOP - Management and Operation of Microsoft 365.pdf

text_chunk:
5.8. Teams

5.8.1. Users are prohibited from creating Teams. They must submit a request, and an Administrator will handle the setup.

5.8.2. Before creating Teams, Administrators must assess the user request and use case to determine if Teams is appropriate. Teams is best suited for collaboration with defined groups (departments, project teams, or cross-functional groups).

5.8.3. External sharing in Teams must be disabled by default. Exceptions require documented approval.

5.8.4. Inactive Teams must be regularly audited, with archiving or deletion as appropriate.
source: SOP - Management and Operation of Microsoft 365.pdf

text_chunk:
5.9. SharePoint

5.9.1. Users are prohibited from creating SharePoint sites. They must submit a request, and an Administrator will handle the setup.

5.9.2. Before creating a SharePoint site, Administrators must assess the user request and use case to determine if SharePoint is appropriate. SharePoint is best suited for document management and structured repositories, and for storing information that needs controlled lifecycle management and wider visibility beyond small groups.

5.9.3. External sharing in sites must be disabled by default. Exceptions require documented approval.

5.9.4. "Everyone" or anonymous access is prohibited. Exceptions require documented approval.

5.9.5. Hub sites must be used to organize and govern departmental SharePoint sites.

5.9.6. Each SharePoint site must have at least two Site Owners.

5.9.7. Site permissions should be granted via security groups rather than individuals. The use of dynamic security groups is recommended for establishing minimum permissions baselines for sites. For example, all users in a particular department (~sec_dyn_dep_Accion Advisory) having "View" permissions to the departmental site.

5.9.8. When required, unique permissions should only be applied at the document library levels. They should never be applied to folder or file levels.

5.9.9. Where applicable, access requests should be routed to Site Owners.

5.9.10. The default setting for file and folder link sharing must be configured as "Specific people (only the individuals explicitly designated by the user).

5.9.11. The default permission for shared file and folder links must be configured as "View" rather than "Edit".

5.9.12. "Anyone" links must have an expiration date enforced.

5.9.13. Inactive sites must be regularly audited, with archiving or deletion as appropriate.
source: SOP - Management and Operation of Microsoft 365.pdf

text_chunk:
5.10. Exchange

5.10.1. User mailboxes must be created only for active employees with valid business need.

5.10.2. Mailbox permissions (e.g., Full Access, Send As) must be granted through groups where possible, not directly to individuals.

5.10.3. Inactive or orphaned mailboxes must be reviewed and decommissioned promptly.

5.10.4. Automatic external forwarding must be disabled by default and only allowed by exception with documented business justification.

5.10.5. Internal automatic forwarding should be limited and tracked for accountability.

5.10.6. Forwarding rules must be reviewed periodically to prevent data exfiltration risks.

5.10.7. Shared mailboxes must be used for team- or role-based communication instead of personal accounts.

5.10.8. Shared mailboxes must not have direct login credentials. Access must be through delegated permissions.

5.10.9. The GT Ops team shall use the GTOps@accion.org shared mailbox for the purpose of centralizing GT Ops activities that require team visibility. This includes alerts such as admin consents for app requests, billing notifications, GT vendor notifications, etc. The GTOps@accion.org shared mailbox may include email aliases such as GTVendors@accion.org. This shared mailbox must be monitored daily by the GT Ops team, and emails in this mailbox must be filed appropriately on a weekly basis in the Inbox subfolder(s).

5.10.10. Online archiving must be enabled for all user mailboxes to ensure compliance, per organizational retention requirements.

5.10.11. Users should be educated on using Online Archive for long-term retention.

5.10.12. Distribution groups must be used for email communication to defined sets of users.

5.10.13. Distribution groups membership must be maintained regularly and reflect current business needs.

5.10.14. Owner(s) must be assigned for each distribution group to ensure accountability.

5.10.15. Dynamic distribution groups must be used when membership is driven by attributes (e.g., department, location). Changes to dynamic membership rules must be thoroughly tested and validated before changes are made effective.

5.10.16. Mail-enabled security groups should not be used in a cloud-only environment, unless there is a specific use case.

5.10.17. MailTips must be enabled for large distribution lists to prevent accidental broad communications.

5.10.18. Mail flow rules must be configured to enforce compliance, security, and branding requirements (e.g., disclaimers, encryption).

5.10.19. Mail flow rules must be documented with clear descriptions of purpose and scope.

5.10.20. Redundant or conflicting mail flow rules must be avoided. Rules must be reviewed periodically.

5.10.21. Name and email address changes must always be requested by HR.
5.10.21.1. Username and/or User Principal Name (UPN) must not be changed unless necessary.
5.10.21.2. When a user's email address is changed, the previous email address must be maintained as an alias.

5.10.22. DMARC must be configured on the domain(s) according to best practices:
5.10.22.1. SPF records must be published with only authorized mail servers included.
5.10.22.2. DKIM signing must be enabled for outbound mail to validate message integrity.
5.10.22.3. DMARC policies must be configured, tested, and progressively enforced (monitor quarantine → reject).
5.10.22.4. DMARC reports must be regularly reviewed to identify unauthorized senders and remediate accordingly.
source: SOP - Management and Operation of Microsoft 365.pdf

text_chunk:
5.11. Copilot

5.11.1. Users must receive training on responsible use, data security, and Al limitations.

5.11.2. Copilot must not be enabled in unmanaged environments
source: SOP - Management and Operation of Microsoft 365.pdf

text_chunk:
5.12. Licensing

5.12.1. Licenses must be consistently procured via approved vendors and resellers (e.g.. FSi).

5.12.2. Licenses must be assigned via groups rather than individually to ensure consistency.

5.12.3. Licensing utilization must be reviewed monthly and essential licenses replenished accordingly.

5.12.4. Disabled or inactive accounts must not retain active licenses.

5.12.5. A tiered risk-based licensing model must be maintained, aligned to role-based needs and risk profiles. Below are the baseline requirements and the corresponding license model assignments for different types of users:
[Table data omitted for brevity: FTE, PTE, FIXT, PEO, CON-I, CON-E, TMP require Conditional Access, Information Protection, Defender for Endpoint Plan 2, Intune]

5.12.6. Refer to "Section 6.2 - M365 Maps Feature Matrix" for more information on M365 licenses and subscriptions.

5.12.7. Users that are part of the AIM legal entity are required to have the add-on license: "M365 Information Protection and Governance".
source: SOP - Management and Operation of Microsoft 365.pdf

text_chunk:
5.13. Backup

5.13.1. A cloud-to-cloud backup solution must be implemented to protect Microsoft 365 data across Exchange, SharePoint, OneDrive, and Teams.

5.13.2. Backup solution must operate independently of Microsoft's native retention and recovery features.

5.13.3. Backup frequency and retention policies must align with organizational compliance and business continuity requirements.

5.13.4. Backup data must be encrypted in transit and at rest.

5.13.5. Access to the backup system must be restricted to authorized administrators only and protected with MFA.

5.13.6. Restore procedures must be documented, tested periodically, and reviewed at least annually.

5.13.7. Alerts and reporting must be enabled to monitor backup health, failures, and anomalies.

5.13.8. Backup vendor/service providers must meet organizational security, compliance, and data residency requirements.
source: SOP - Management and Operation of Microsoft 365.pdf

6. References

6.1. M365 Naming Conventions and Standardized Properties
6.2. M365 Maps Feature Matrix
6.3. Information Security Exception Request Form

7. Version History
Version 1.0: Initial release (10/18/2025)

text_chunk:
1. Purpose
The purpose of this Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) is to establish a unified process for procuring, deploying, and managing all end-user computers issued by Accion. It defines standard practices to ensure that employees, contractors, consultants, interns, and other authorized personnel are equipped with appropriate computer hardware, and that these assets are tracked and refreshed in a consistent, secure, and cost-effective manner across Accion’s global offices and remote locations. This SOP aims to align device procurement with business needs (by role and department), maintain minimum hardware standards, and outline the lifecycle from purchase to decommissioning.

2. Scope
This SOP applies to all Accion locations worldwide, including major hubs (e.g. Washington DC, Bogota Colombia, and Mumbai India offices) as well as fully remote staff. It covers all organization-issued computers (laptops and similar devices) provided to Accion’s workforce. It encompasses devices issued to full-time and part-time employees, contractors, consultants, temporary staff, interns/externs, and volunteers (essentially anyone receiving an Accion-owned computer for business use).
In-Scope Devices: Standard end-user computing hardware, primarily laptops (Windows notebooks such as Lenovo ThinkPad series and Microsoft Surface, and Apple MacBook devices). Desktop computers are currently not issued but would follow this SOP if provided. All issued computers are considered organization property and must adhere to this SOP throughout their lifecycle.
source: SOP - Computer Procurement and Lifecycle Management_draft.docx

text_chunk:
3. Roles & Responsibilities

Global Technology Operations (GT Ops) team
Responsible for executing day-to-day procurement and deployment of computers per this SOP. This includes maintaining the list of approved standard models and specifications, enrolling devices in management systems (Intune), and ensuring compliance with security and naming standards.
The GT Ops team coordinates with vendors and business partners for purchasing and with end-users for device setup.

Department Managers / Requestors
When a new device is needed (for a new hire or a replacement), the manager or the employee must initiate an official request.
Managers are responsible for approving device requests for their team members and ensuring the request aligns with business needs and the standards in this SOP.
They also facilitate return of any old equipment when staff leave or devices are refreshed.

GT Ops Leadership
Provides oversight and must approve any exceptions to standard models or specifications.
Ensures the procurement strategy aligns with budget and strategic partnerships. For example, selecting preferred vendors and approving high-cost purchases (like high-end models for special use) falls under their purview.
Reviews and approves updates to this SOP.

Finance
Ensures funding is available and tracks capital expenditure for equipment.
Finance may set annual budgets for hardware refresh cycles, informed by forecasts from GT.

End Users
Users of Accion computers are responsible for following GT policies in use of the device.
They must promptly inform GT Ops if a device is malfunctioning, lost, or in need of replacement.
Upon off-boarding or device refresh, users must return the device to Accion (or follow shipping instructions for remote staff). All company property must be returned when a user’s engagement ends.
source: SOP - Computer Procurement and Lifecycle Management_draft.docx

text_chunk:
4. Definitions

Computer/Device: Refers to an Accion-issued end-user computing device, predominantly a laptop computer (Windows or Mac). It includes any standard accessories provided (power adapter, etc.).

Intune: Microsoft’s cloud-based device management platform used by Accion to enroll, configure, secure, and monitor all corporate laptops. Intune serves as the source of truth for our active computer inventory, recording device details (make, model, serial number, OS, compliance status). Compliance policies (encryption, up-to-date patching, etc.) in Intune enforce security requirements on all enrolled devices.

Standard Models: The list of laptop models approved for use at Accion based on evaluated quality, performance, and vendor support. Currently this list includes Lenovo ThinkPad X1 Carbon, Lenovo ThinkPad T14s, Microsoft Surface Laptop, Apple MacBook Pro, and Apple MacBook Air. These models cover a range of use-cases from high-performance to general office work.

Minimum Specifications: The baseline hardware configuration that all new laptops must meet. This includes CPU type, RAM, storage, etc. “Recommended” specifications refer to higher-tier configurations for demanding use (e.g. more memory or faster processors for power users).

Lifecycle Stages: For the purposes of refresh planning, Accion classifies devices by age: Current (new or up to ~2 years from manufacturer release), Midlife (~3 years old), and Legacy (≥4 years old, due for retirement). This classification is primarily based on the laptop model’s original manufacturer release year, which serves as a proxy for its technology age. (E.g. a laptop model released in 2023 is “Current” in 2025; a model released in 2021 or earlier would be “Legacy” by 2025 and slated for replacement.)

Asset Aging: The process of identifying older computers that may need replacement. Accion uses manufacturer release dates and Intune data to flag aging assets. If a device’s model is over ~4 years old or its performance is noticeably degraded, it is considered to be at end-of-life in our environment.

Disposition: The formal process for decommissioning a device that is being retired. Disposition includes data wiping, asset deregistration, and physically disposing of or recycling the hardware through approved e-waste vendors or donation channels per Accion policy. Until disposition is complete, retired devices remain on record (with a status) to track that they have been removed from service.
source: SOP - Computer Procurement and Lifecycle Management_draft.docx

text_chunk:
5.1. Procurement Workflow and Approvals

Request Initiation: All computer purchases must be initiated through an official request to the Global Technology team. Trigger events include new hire onboarding, replacement of aging equipment, role change requiring an upgraded device, or irreparable hardware failure. For new employees, HR or the hiring manager will raise an equipment request in advance of the start date. For existing staff, the user or their manager submits a request (via a ticket or procurement form) detailing the need (e.g. “laptop slow, 4 years old, needs refresh”).

Manager Approval: The employee’s manager (or department head) must approve the request for a new or replacement computer. This ensures budgetary accountability and that the device aligns with the user’s role. Managers should verify that a replacement is warranted (checking device age or performance issues). In cases of early replacement (before reaching Legacy age), justification is required (e.g. device lost, damaged, or job requirements outgrew the current specs).

Standard Model Selection: GT Ops will recommend a device model based on the user’s role and the standard model guidelines. In general, requests should be fulfilled with one of the approved standard models. If the user’s needs fall under a certain category (e.g. an executive requesting a lightweight model due to travel or health reasons), GT Ops may select the appropriate standard model (e.g. ThinkPad X1 for its lighter weight or a MacBook for a design role). Non-standard models or custom configurations are not typically allowed, and any exception must be reviewed by GT Ops leadership. GT Ops may continuously replenish and maintain a stock inventory of up to 5 computers based on demand and forecast.

Quote and Vendor Selection: Once the model and specs are determined, GT Ops (or Procurement) obtains quotes from approved vendors. Accion maintains relationships with preferred suppliers in different regions (for example, InfoSols in India as a primary vendor, and Haavit Retail as an alternate). Standard practice is to favor the primary vendor to strengthen partnerships, unless there is a significant price difference or stock unavailability. Vendors are expected to include at least a 3-year warranty and accident damage coverage in the quote. The requestor’s local context (e.g. in-country vendor vs. international shipping) is considered to avoid delays in delivery.

Approval for Purchase: The compiled quote and model recommendation are presented for final approval. If the cost is within budget and it’s a routine issuance (standard model for a new hire or scheduled refresh), GT Ops can approve and proceed. If the item is high-value or off-cycle, additional approval from GT Leadership or Finance may be required. For example, purchasing a high-end model like a max-spec MacBook Pro for a user would be escalated for approval due to higher cost. Bulk procurements (like refreshing a batch of 50+ laptops) should also have Finance’s approval as part of annual budgeting.

Order Placement: Upon approval, GT Ops (or business partner) places the order with the selected vendor, referencing the approved quote. They ensure the order includes the correct specifications and any asset tagging instructions if applicable. If the device is needed urgently and a vendor has a long lead time (e.g. certain models like custom-configured T14s might have a 5-week lead time), GT Ops may opt for an alternative model or check other suppliers to meet the required timeline. In some cases, an internal inventory solution can be used (e.g. reassigning a recently returned laptop) to meet an immediate need.

Delivery and Asset Recording: The device is shipped to the appropriate location. For hub offices, it may be delivered to IT stock. For remote staff, it can be direct-shipped to the user with coordination. Upon receiving the device, GT Ops updates the asset inventory: recording the serial number, model, purchase date, warranty period, assigned user, and asset tag if used. This record is typically maintained in Intune.
source: SOP - Computer Procurement and Lifecycle Management_draft.docx

text_chunk:
5.2. Standard Specifications and Configuration

Minimum Hardware Requirements: All computers procured must meet a baseline standard to ensure sufficient performance and longevity. As of this SOP, the minimum spec for any new laptop is: Intel Core i5 (12th Gen or newer) or Apple Silicon M1 chip, 16 GB RAM, and 512 GB SSD storage. Many standard builds will actually come with an Intel Core i7 processor and 32GB by default for long-term viability.

Standard Configurations by Role: To streamline procurement and simplify support, GT Ops maintains a few pre-defined laptop configurations that correspond to typical use cases. For example, a “Standard Office” config (e.g. ThinkPad T14s with Intel i7, 32GB RAM, 1TB SSD) covers the majority of staff needs, whereas an “Executive/Power User” config (ThinkPad X1 or MacBook Pro with 64GB RAM, 1TB SSD) is available for those who need extra power or travel frequently.

Operating System and Software: All new Windows laptops must be ordered with Windows 11 Pro (64-bit) by default (English language; localized keyboard if needed per region). Macs come with macOS and will be upgraded to the latest supported macOS version. Upon receipt, GT Ops will enroll the device in Intune (if not already via Autopilot) and apply the standard Accion configuration profile. This includes: installing required software (productivity suite, security tools), applying BitLocker encryption, setting up device naming per conventions, and verifying compliance policies (MFA, etc.).

Warranty and Protection: Every Windows computer purchased must include a minimum 3-year warranty ideally with Accidental Damage Protection (ADP) from the manufacturer or vendor. This is to cover hardware failures and accidental drops/spills during the standard lifecycle. For instance, Lenovo quotes are obtained with 3 Year Premier Support + ADP.

Naming Convention: In alignment with Accion’s established naming standards, all end-user computers are named using their serial number as the device name in our directories and Intune. For example, a laptop with serial ABC123456 would have hostname “ABC123456”. This convention ensures uniqueness and easy tracking of devices across systems. (Intune and Entra ID will reflect this name upon enrollment.) The naming is applied during device setup. No departmental prefixes or personal names are used in hostnames, to keep names consistent and avoid confusion when devices are reassigned. Refer to "Section 6.1 M365 Naming Conventions and Standardized Properties".
source: SOP - Computer Procurement and Lifecycle Management_draft.docx

text_chunk:
5.3. Device Allocation by Seniority, Department, and Use-Case

Not all users have the same computing needs. Accion’s standard models are mapped to user categories to ensure each individual gets a machine appropriate for their job while controlling costs.

Executive Leadership (C-Level, SVPs, VPs, Board-facing roles): Lenovo ThinkPad X1 Carbon (Gen 12+) or Surface Laptop Copilot+ 13.8” or Apple MacBook Pro 14”. Premium, high-performance ultrabook for heavy use. Lightweight for travel.

Senior Management (Directors, Technical Leads): Lenovo ThinkPad X1 Carbon (or T14s) or Apple MacBook Pro/Air. Senior staff often travel or multitask heavily, so the X1 Carbon (14″, i7/32GB) is recommended for Windows users as a balance of power and mobility.

General Staff / Standard Office Roles (Professional staff, support staff): Lenovo ThinkPad T14s or Surface Laptop. The T14s is the standard issue for the majority of employees. It’s a 14″ business laptop with robust build and good performance (typically i5/i7 with 32GB) at a lower cost than. It meets general office needs.

Creative / Design / Communications (High multimedia use): Apple MacBook Pro 14″ or 16″ (M-series). macOS is often preferred for design and multimedia. These users are provided with MacBook Pros with upgraded specs (at least 32-64GB RAM, larger SSD) to handle graphics, video editing, and design software.

Contractors / Consultants (Short-term engagements): Lenovo ThinkPad T14s (existing spare). Contractors and interns typically receive a standard T14s or an available older unit, rather than a brand-new top-spec device, especially for short tenures.

The above allocations are guidelines. Individual exceptions can be made with approval. The goal is to align seniority and job function with an appropriate device to maximize productivity.
source: SOP - Computer Procurement and Lifecycle Management_draft.docx

text_chunk:
5.4. Asset Lifecycle Management (Refresh & Aging)

Lifecycle Planning: We target a 4-year replacement cycle for laptops under normal use. This means after about 4 years in service, a device is considered for upgrade. This aligns with typical warranty periods (3 years + 1 year grace) and industry benchmarks for laptop lifespans. However, rather than strictly by purchase date, we consider the model release year as an indicator of device age relative to current technology.

Categorization of Assets by Age: GT Ops maintains a dynamic inventory report (via Intune and PowerBI) that groups all devices into categories by model year. The following Lifecycle Stages are used:
- Current (Deploy): Devices with model release in the last ~2 years. These are cutting-edge and fully supported.
- Midlife (Support): Devices released ~3 years ago. These are still supported and generally meet requirements, but we begin to monitor them more closely.
- Legacy (Retire): Devices with model release ≥4 years ago. These are considered end-of-life in our environment and are planned for retirement/replacement. They may still function, but performance, battery life, or supportability is likely a concern.

Annual Refresh Cycle: Each year, typically in Q4 during budget planning or Q1 of the new year, GT Ops will generate the list of devices in the Legacy category and prioritize them for replacement. At a high level, we expect to replace roughly 20–25% of the laptop fleet annually, which corresponds to a four-year full refresh cycle.

Execution of Refresh: For each device identified for refresh, GT Ops will schedule a replacement following the procurement process. Often, these replacements are spread across the year to manage workload and cash flow, rather than all at once. Users with Legacy devices are notified to expect a new laptop. New devices are configured and issued, and the old devices are collected. GT Ops updates the asset records to mark the old device as “retired” and the new one as active for that user.

Exceptions & Extensions: If a device in Legacy category is still performing adequately and the user is satisfied (or if budget constraints prevent immediate replacement), GT Ops may defer its replacement by up to one additional year. We monitor such extended devices carefully for any signs of failure. On the other hand, if a device in Midlife category shows performance issues, we might replace it early to avoid hindering the user’s productivity.
source: SOP - Computer Procurement and Lifecycle Management_draft.docx

text_chunk:
5.5. Device Retirement, Return, and Disposition

User Offboarding/Device Return: If a user is leaving Accion or receiving a replacement device, the old device must be returned to GT Ops. For on-site staff, the laptop is turned in on the user’s last day (HR and GT coordinate as part of an exit checklist). For remote staff, GT Ops provides a prepaid shipping label to return the laptop to the nearest Accion office or directly to an IT asset processing center. All Accion property must be returned. Exceptions (like a departing staff wishing to buy their old laptop) are generally not allowed unless explicitly approved by Finance and GT (and even then, the device would be wiped).

Data Safeguard and Wipe: Once a device is in GT Ops’s custody, Intune Retire/Wipe command is issued. This action removes all Accion data and configurations: it will either fully erase the device (factory reset) or at least remove corporate profiles and encrypt the data such that it’s inaccessible.

Evaluation for Reuse or Donation: Depending on condition, some retired laptops can have a second life. Accion’s policy is to reuse viable hardware internally first (for temps or testing), and if not needed, consider donation to partner organizations only with proper data wipe and removal of any licenses. Any donation must be authorized by GT Leadership and Finance, and the device must be stripped of all Accion software and data.

E-Waste Disposal: Hardware that is end-of-life or not suitable for reuse is disposed of through environmentally responsible e-waste channels. Accion will work with certified e-waste recyclers to ensure components are recycled or destroyed according to local regulations.
source: SOP - Computer Procurement and Lifecycle Management_draft.docx
